are consistent with the observed geographic distribution of blacklegged ticks for the period 2003 to 2013 ( Bouchard et al. 2015; Ogden et al. 2014a) ( Figure 1). The surveillance data from Bouchard et al. ( 2015) and Ogden et al. ( 2014a) showed that few tick populations were found in the warmest parts of Ontario, which may be attributed to the relative lack of woodland habitat ( Clow et al. 2016). Additionally, the predicted evolution of
R 0
estimates for southern Ontario and Nova Scotia were compared with the evolution in the number of Canadian Census Subdivisions (CSD) with probable established I. scapularis populations over the years between 1991 and 2008, estimated from surveillance data by Leighton et al. ( 2012). In the two selected regions, tick populations started to emerge, after a period of sustained warming, increasing
R 0
toward or over 2 for several consecutive years (2000 to 2005 in Ontario and 1998 to 2003 in Nova Scotia) (Figures S1 and S2).
